newsitem.title: YUGOSLAVIA: Ten hurt in Yugoslav court grenade attack.
newsitem.headline: Ten hurt in Yugoslav court grenade attack.

text.p: Ten people were wounded when a defendant threw a hand grenade at a woman judge in a courtroom near Belgrade, news reports said on Friday.
A major tragedy was averted when the judge, Ksenija Ivkovic, dived for the hand grenade and flung it into a corner of the packed courthouse, Belgrade news agency Fonet said.
"Thanks to the judge's presence of mind, 10 people in the courtroom were not injured as seriously as they would (otherwise) have been," it said.

The agency said two of the 10 wounded in Thursday's incident were in serious condition, while the defendant, Aleksandar Tomic, was unhurt. News reports said Tomic was a Serb refugee, but did not say whether he was from Bosnia or Croatia.
The 52-year old taxi driver had another, more lethal hand grenade in his possession but failed to activate it before the police overpowered him.
Serbia is awash with weapons after 1991-1995 wars in Croatia and Bosnia, and crime and homicide are on the rise while the country's economy continues to decline.
Tomic was facing charges of making deadly threats against his neighbours.
